1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: Measles-mumps-rubella vaccination: 0.5 mL SUBQ, first dose at 12 to 15 months and second dose at 4 to 6 years; do not delay first dose past 15 months of age because of increased risk of postvaccination seizures; may give second dose before age 4 years as long as at least 28 days have elapsed since the first dose.

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• active febrile infection or febrile respiratory illness (manufacturer); acute illness with or without fever, moderate or severe; defer vaccination unless the benefit of protection outweighs the risk of an adverse reaction (CDC)
  • anaphylactic or anaphylactoid reactions to neomycin; reconstituted vaccine contains approximately 25 mcg/dose; history of contact dermatitis, delayed-type cell-mediated immune response to neomycin is not a contraindication
  • bone marrow or lymphatic disorders, including blood dyscrasias, leukemia, lymphomas of any type, and other malignant neoplasms affecting the bone marrow or lymphatic systems
  • concomitant immunosuppressive therapy, except corticosteroids as replacement therapy (eg, Addison's disease)
  • congenital or hereditary immunodeficiency, family history, until immunocompetence of potential vaccine recipient is verified
  • hypersensitivity to any component of the vaccine, including gelatin
  • HIV with severe immunocompromise (age-specific CD4+ T-lymphocyte less than 15%) (CDC) including AIDS- and HIV-associated infections (manufacturer)
  • immunodeficiency, severe (eg, from hematologic and solid tumors, congenital immunodeficiency, long-term immunosuppressive therapy (prednisolone 20 mg or 2 mg/kg daily or equivalent corticosteroid for 2 weeks or longer)), primary or acquired immunodeficiency, cellular immune deficiencies, and hypogammaglobulinemic/dysgammaglobulinemic states; measles inclusion body encephalitis, pneumonitis, and death have been reported in immunocompromised persons inadvertently vaccinated with measles-containing vaccine (manufacturer)
  • pregnancy; avoid pregnancy for 3 months following vaccination

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• antibody-containing products; blood or plasma transfusions or immune globulin administration within previous 11 months (specific interval depends on product)
  • cerebral injury, history, or any condition where stress due to temperature elevation should be avoided
  • concomitant chemotherapy or radiation therapy; live vaccine should not be administered for at least 3 months unless benefit outweighs risk of adverse reactions
  • convulsions, individual or family history or any condition where stress due to temperature elevation should be avoided
  • HIV-infected patients without immunocompromise; immunization may be less effective
  • hypersensitivity (anaphylactic, anaphylactoid, or immediate reaction after ingestion) to eggs; vaccine contains trace chick embryo antigen; evaluate risk-to-benefit ratio; does not include allergies to chickens or chicken feathers
  • TB, untreated, active or suspected; do not vaccinate until after treatment
  • TB skin test; temporary depression of test sensitivity; administer test before or simultaneously with MMR vaccine or unless urgent postpone test until at least 4 weeks after MMR vaccination
  • thrombocytopenia, current or history or history of thrombocytopenic purpura; potential exacerbation or development with repeated doses; evaluate risk-to-benefit ratio
  • women of childbearing age; avoid pregnancy for 3 months following vaccination
  • report suspected adverse events to Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS) at 1-800-822-7967

sub.title: Pregnancy Category
sub.mono:
• Measles Virus Vaccine, Live: C (FDA)
  • Mumps Virus Vaccine, Live: C (FDA)
  • Mumps Virus Vaccine, Live: B2 (AUS)
  • Rubella Virus Vaccine, Live: C (FDA)
  • Rubella Virus Vaccine, Live: B2 (AUS)

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• Measles Virus Vaccine, Live: WHO: Compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Measles Virus Vaccine, Live: Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.
  • Mumps Virus Vaccine, Live: WHO: Compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Mumps Virus Vaccine, Live: Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.
  • Rubella Virus Vaccine, Live: WHO: Compatible with breast-feeding.
  • Rubella Virus Vaccine, Live: Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Injection site reaction
  • Musculoskeletal:Arthralgia, Arthritis
  • Other:Fever
Serious
  • Dermatologic:Erythema multiforme, Stevens-Johnson syndrome
  • Gastrointestinal:Pancreatitis
  • Hematologic:Thrombocytopenia
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis
  • Neurologic:Afebrile seizure, Encephalitis, Encephalopathy, Febrile seizure, Guillain-Barr syndrome, Measles inclusion body encephalitis
  • Ophthalmic:Optic neuritis, Retrobulbar neuritis
  • Respiratory:Pneumonitis

sub.title: Synonyms
sub.mono:
• MMR Vaccine - Measles, Mumps, and Rubella Virus Vaccine, Live
  • Measles, Mumps, and Rubella Virus Vaccine, Live

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Measles, mumps and rubella vaccine is a live virus vaccine preparation for simultaneous vaccination against measles (rubeola), mumps and rubella (German measles) diseases. It is highly immunogenic and stimulates measles hemagglutination-inhibition (HI) antibodies, mumps neutralizing antibodies and rubella HI antibodies in susceptible individuals.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    for SUBQ use only; do not administer IV or IM
  • Subcutaneous
    • do not give concurrently with immune globulin
    • give preferably into outer aspect of upper arm
    • reconstitute with supplied diluent; shake well
    • use within 8 hours of reconstitution
    • should be given 1 month before or after administration of other live viral vaccines

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Counsel female patients of childbearing age to use reliable contraception to avoid pregnancy for at least 3 months post-vaccination.
  • This vaccination should be deferred at least 3 months following blood or plasma transfusions and administration of immune globulin.
  • This drug may cause arthralgia or arthritis in female patients. Drug may also cause lymphadenopathy, myalgia, or symptoms of the common cold.
  • Advise patient to report fever or signs/symptoms of thrombocytopenia or Stevens-Johnson syndrome (flu-like symptoms, spreading red rash, or skin/mucous membrane blistering).
  • Patient should also report signs/symptoms of optic neuritis, polyneuritis, or polyneuropathy.
  • Tell patient to avoid other vaccines one month before or one month after having this vaccine, unless approved by healthcare professional.
  • Advise pediatric patients to call healthcare professional if a vaccination is missed, as drug should be given in a fixed series.
